article.paragraph: Brigitte Anne-Marie Bardotcite webhttp://rateyourmusic.com/artist/brigitte_bardotFilms and Music by Brigitte BardotRate Your Music13 March 2010cite webhttp://www.dailycelebrations.com/092800.htmDaily Celebrations ~ Brigitte Bardot, Cat TransformedDailycelebrations.com13 March 2010(IPA-frbʁiʒit baʁˈdolang; born 28 September 1934) is aFrench peopleFrenchformer actress, singer and fashion model, who later became an animal rights activist. She was one of the best knownsex symbolsof the 1950s and 1960s and was widely referred to by her initials.Institut Francais Royaume-Uni, And Bardot Became BBStarting in 1969, Bardot became the official face ofMarianne(who had previously been anonymous) to represent the liberty of France.Anne-Marie Sohn (teacher at thecole Normale SuprieureENS-Lyon),Marianne ou l'histoire de l'ide rpublicaine aux XIXe et XXe sicles la lumire de ses reprsentations(rsum of Maurice Agulhon's three books,Marianne au combat,Marianne au pouvoirandLes mtamorphoses de Marianne)fr icon

Bardot was an aspiring ballerina in early life. She started her acting career in 1952 and after appearing in 16 routine comedy films, with limited international release, became world-famous in 1957, with the controversial filmAnd God Created Woman (1956 film)And God Created Woman. She later starred inJean-Luc Godard's 1963 filmContempt (film)Le Mpris. For her role inLouis Malle's 1965 filmViva Maria!Bardot was nominated for aBAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading RoleBAFTA Award for Best Foreign Actress. Bardot caught the attention of French intellectuals. She was the subject ofSimone de Beauvoir's 1959 essay,The Lolita Syndrome, which described Bardot as a "locomotive of women's history" and built uponexistentialistthemes to declare her the first and most liberated woman of post-war France.

Bardot retired from the entertainment industry in 1973. During her career in show business, she starred in 47 films, performed in several musical shows and recorded over 60 songs. She was awarded theLegion of Honourin 1985 but refused to receive it."The Big Question: How does the French honours system work, and why has Kylie been decorated?", independent.co.uk, 8 May 2008.After her retirement, she established herself as ananimal rightsactivist. During the 1990s, she generated controversy by criticizing immigration andIslam in Franceand has been fined five times forIncitement to ethnic or racial hatredinciting racial hatred.cite newsBardot fine for stoking race hate3 June 2008http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7434193.stm3 June 2008BBC NewsLondon, UKcite newsBardot fined for racist remarks16 June 2000http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/793390.stm4 June 2008BBC NewsLondon, UK
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Bardot was born inParis, the daughter of Louis Bardot (18961975) and Anne-Marie "Toty" Bardot (ne Mucel; 19121978). Louis had an engineering degree and worked with his father, Charles Bardot, in the family business. Louis and Anne-Marie married in 1933. Bardot grew up in a upper middle-classRoman Catholicobservant home.cite newshttp://www.tribune.ie/article/2009/sep/27/profile-brigitte-bardot-and-god-created-bardotProfile: Brigitte Bardot – And God created Bardot[[Sunday Tribune]]27 September 200919 September 2010ValerieShanleyWhen she was seven she was admitted to theCours Hattemer, a private school. She went to school three days a week, and otherwise studied at home. This gave time for lessons at Madame Bourget's dance studio three days a week.cite bookSingerBarnettBrigitte Bardot: A Biographyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2015-07-012006-07-06McFarland978-0-7864-8426-310–11Brigitte's mother also enrolled Brigitte's younger sister, Marie-Jeanne (born 5 May 1938), in dance. Marie-Jeanne eventually gave up dancing lessons and did not tell her mother, whereas Brigitte concentrated on ballet. In 1947, Bardot was accepted to theConservatoire de Paris. For three years she attended ballet classes by Russian choreographer Boris Knyazev. One of her classmates wasLeslie Caron. The other ballerinas nicknamed Bardot "Bichette" ("Little Doe").Leslie CaronCaron, Leslie.Thank Heaven, Plume Publishing (2009)

At the invitation of an acquaintance of her mother, she modelled in a fashion show in 1949. In the same year, she modelled for a fashion magazine "Jardin des Modes" managed by journalist Hlne Lazareff. Aged 15, she appeared on an 8 March 1950 cover ofElle (magazine)Ellecite webhttp://thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_story/830:112/1/Brigitte_Bardot.htmBrigitte Bardot BiographyThe Biography Channel13 March 2010and was noticed by a young film director,Roger Vadim, while babysitting. He showed an issue of the magazine to director and screenwriterMarc Allgret, who offered Bardot the opportunity to audition forLes lauriers sont coups. Although Bardot got the role, the film was cancelled but made her consider becoming an actress. Her acquaintance with Vadim, who attended the audition, influenced her further life and career.
article.heading: Career
article.paragraph: Although theEuropean cinemaEuropean film industrywas then in its ascendancy, Bardot was one of the few European actresses to have the mass media's attention in the United States, an interest which she did not reciprocate. She debuted in a 1952comedy film,Le Trou Normand(English title:Crazy for Love). From 1952 to 1956, she appeared in seventeen films; in 1953 she played a role inJean Anouilh's stageplayL'Invitation au Chteau(Invitation to the Castle). She received media attention when she attended theCannes Film Festivalin April 1953.

File:Brigitte Bardot - 1965.jpgthumbleftBrigitte Bardot and the youngBilly Mumyin ''Dear Brigitte,'' 1965.Herfilms of the early and mid 1950s were generally lightweight romantic dramas, some historical, in which she was cast asIngenue (stock character)ingnueorSiren (mythology)siren, often appearing nude or nearly so. She played bit parts in three English-language films, the British comedyDoctor at Sea (film)Doctor at Sea(1955) withDirk Bogarde,Helen of Troy (film)Helen of Troy(1954), in which she was understudy for theHelen of Troytitle rolebut appears only as Helen's handmaid andAct of Love(1954) withKirk Douglas. Her French-language films were dubbed for international release.Roger Vadim(her husband) was not content with this light fare. TheFrench New WaveNew WaveofFrench cinemaFrenchandItalian cinemaItalianart directors and their stars were riding high internationally and he felt Bardot was being undersold. Looking for something more like an art film to push her as a serious actress, he showcased her inAnd God Created Woman (1956 film)And God Created Woman(1956) oppositeJean-Louis Trintignant. The film, about an immoral teenager in a respectable small-town setting, was a huge success and turned Bardot into an international star.

During her early career, professional photographer Sam Lvin's photos contributed to her image of Bardot's sensuality. One showed Bardot from behind, dressed in a white corset. British photographerCornel Lucasmade images of Bardot in the 1950s and 1960s, that have become representative of her public persona.File:Brigitte Bardot.jpgthumbrightBardot in 1968.Shedivorced Vadim in 1957. In 1959, she married actorJacques Charrier, with whom she starred inBabette Goes to War. The press took great interest in her marriage, while she and her husband clashed over the direction of her career. Bardot's only child, Nicolas-Jacques Charrier, was a product of her marriage to Jacques Charrier.cnAugust 2015

Bardot was awarded aDavid di DonatelloDavid di Donatello Awardfor Best Foreign actress for her role inA Very Private Affair(Vie prive, 1962), directed byLouis Malle.Awards for Brigitte Bardot info, IMDb.com; retrieved 21 August 2010

In May 1958, Bardot withdrew to the seclusion ofSouthern France, where she had bought the houseLa MadragueinSaint-Tropez. In 1963, she starred inJean-Luc Godard's filmContempt (film)Le Mpris. Bardot was featured in many other films along with notable actors such asAlain Delon(Famous Love Affairs;Spirits of the Dead);Jean Gabin(In Case of Adversity);Sean Connery(Shalako (film)Shalako);Jean Marais(Royal Affairs in Versailles;School for Love);Lino Ventura(Rum Runners);Annie Girardot(The Novices);Claudia Cardinale(The Legend of Frenchie King);Jeanne Moreau(Viva Maria!);Jane Birkin(Don Juan, or If Don Juan Were a Woman). Her career had traversed epochs where it was possible to say, "In the Sixties and early Seventies, there was no better known - or more scandalous - movie star on earth. Not since the death of Valentino had a star aroused such insane devotion in their fans."Brigitte Bardot celebrates her 75th birthday, dailymail.co.uk; accessed 4 August 2015.In 1973, Bardot announced she was retiring from acting as "a way to get out elegantly".cite newsBrigitte Bardot Gives Up Films at Age of 39http://news.google.com/newspapers?idUPIThe Modesto BeeModesto, California7 June 1973A-817 August 2010A decade later she was diagnosed with breast cancer, which she survived.Famous breast cancer survivors, ecoglamazine.blogspot.com; accessed 4 August 2015.Famous proof that breast cancer is survivable, beliefnet.com; accessed 4 August 2015.

She participated in several musical shows and recorded many popular songs in the 1960s and 1970s, mostly in collaboration withSerge Gainsbourg, Bob Zagury andSacha Distel, including "Harley Davidson"; "Je Me Donne Qui Me Plat"; "Bubble gum"; "Contact"; "Je Reviendrai Toujours Vers Toi"; "L'Appareil Sous"; "La Madrague"; "On Dmnage"; "Sidonie"; "Tu Veux, Ou Tu Veux Pas?"; "Le Soleil De Ma Vie" (the cover ofStevie Wonder's "You Are the Sunshine of My Life"); and the notorious "Je t'aime... moi non-plus". Bardot pleaded with Gainsbourg not to release this duet and he complied with her wishes; the following year, he rerecorded a version with British-born model and actressJane Birkinthat became a massive hit all over Europe. The version with Bardot was issued in 1986 and became a popular download hit in 2006 whenUniversal Recordsmade its back catalogue available to purchase online, with this version of the song ranking as the third most popular download.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6058742.stmBardot revived as download star17 October 2006BBC News3 August 2010
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: On 21 December 1952, aged 18, Bardot married directorRoger Vadim, seven years her senior. To receive permission from Bardot's parents to marry her, Vadim, originally aRussian OrthodoxChristian, was urged to convert to Catholicism, although it is not clear if he ever did so. They divorced five years later, but remained friends and collaborated in later work.File:Brigitte Bardot - Sami Frey - Saint-Tropez - 1963.jpgthumbBardot andSami Freyin St. Tropez, 1963Bardothad an affair with herAnd God Created Womanco-starJean-Louis Trintignant(married at the time to actressStphane Audran) before her divorce from Vadim.cite bookBrigitteBardotInitiales B.B.Grasset & Fasquelle19962-246-52601-9cite book[[Jeffrey Robinson|Robinson, Jeffrey]]Bardot — Two Lives[[Simon & Schuster]] (London)First British1994ASIN: B000KK1LBMThe two lived together for about two years. Their relationship was complicated by Trintignant's frequent absence due tomilitary serviceand Bardot's affair with musicianGilbert Bcaud, and they eventually separated.

In early 1958, Bardot recovered from a reported nervous breakdown in Italy, according to newspaper reports. A suicide attempt with sleeping pills two days earlier was also noted, but was denied by her public relations manager.cite newshttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/thedailymirror/files/1958_0209_cover.jpgLA times 195821 August 2010The Los Angeles Times

On 18 June 1959, she married actor Jacques Charrier, by whom she had her only child, a son,Nicolas-Jacques Charrier(born 11 January 1960). After she and Charrier divorced in 1962, Nicolas was raised in the Charrier family and did not maintain close contact with Bardot until his adulthood.

Bardot's third marriage was to German millionaire playboyGunter Sachsfrom 14 July 1966 to 1 October 1969.In the 1970s, Bardot lived with sculptor Miroslav Brozek and posed for some of his sculptures. In 1974, Bardot appeared in a nude photo shoot inPlayboymagazine, which celebrated her 40th birthday.File:Brigitte Bardot 1958 Italy.jpgthumbBrigitte Bardot photographed in Italy in 1958.

Bardot's fourth and current husband is Bernard d'Ormale, former adviser ofJean-Marie Le Pen, former leader of the far right party Front National; they have been married since 16 August 1992.cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8503379/Gunter-Sachs.htmlLondonThe Daily TelegraphGunter Sachs9 May 2011
article.heading: Animal welfare activism
article.paragraph: In 1973, before her 39th birthday, Bardot announced her retirement. After appearing in more than forty motion pictures and recording several music albums, most notably withSerge Gainsbourg, she chose to use her fame to promoteanimal rights.

In 1986, she established the Brigitte Bardot Foundation for the Welfare and Protection of Animals.cite webhttp://www.fondationbrigittebardot.fr/site/fbb_a.php?IdPereBrigitte Bardot foundation for the welfare and protection of animalsfondationbrigittebardot.fr21 August 2010She became a vegetarianFollain, John (9 April 2006)Brigitte Bardot profile,The TimesThe Times Online: Life & Style; retrieved 2 April 2009.and raised three million francs to fund the foundation by auctioning off jewellery and personal belongings.

She is a strong animal rights activist and a major opponent of the consumption ofhorse meat. In support of animal protection, she condemnedseal hunting in Canadaduring a visit to that country withPaul Watsonof theSea Shepherd Conservation Society.cite webhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_idHardline warrior in war to save the whale11 January 2010The New Zealand Herald22 September 2011On 25 May 2011 the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society renamed its fast interceptor vessel, MVGojira, asMV Brigitte BardotMV ''Brigitte Bardot''in appreciation of her support.cite webhttp://www.seashepherd.org/news-and-media/news-110525-1.htmlSea Shepherd Conservation SocietySeashepherd.org25 May 201125 December 2012

She once had a neighbour's donkey castrated while looking after it, on the grounds of its "sexual harassment" of her own donkey and mare, for which she was taken to court by the donkey's owner in 1989.cite webhttp://www.photoicon.com/online_features/8PHOTOICON ONLINE FEATURES: Andy Martin: Brigitte BardotPhotoicon.com13 March 2010cite webhttp://www.mrpophistory.com/popculturefiles/askmrpophistory_q359.htmMr Pop HistoryMr Pop History13 March 2010Bardot wrote a 1999 letter to Chinese PresidentJiang Zemin, published in French magazine VSD, in which she accused the Chinese of "torturing bears and killing the world's last tigers and rhinos to makeaphrodisiacs".cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/424734.stmBardot savages Chirac and ChinaBBC News19 August 199913 March 2010London

She has donated more than $140,000 over two years for a massanimal sterilizationsterilizationand adoption program forBucharest'sFree-ranging urban dogstray dogs, estimated to number 300,000.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1196712.stmBardot 'saves' Bucharest's dogsBBC News2 March 200113 March 2010

In August 2010, Bardot addressed a letter to the Queen of Denmark,Margrethe II of Denmark, appealing for the sovereign to halt theWhaling in the Faroe Islandskilling of dolphinsin theFaroe Islands. In the letter, Bardot describes the activity as a "macabre spectacle" that "is a shame for Denmark and the Faroe Islands ... This is not a hunt but a mass slaughter ... an outmoded tradition that has no acceptable justification in today's world".Brigitte Bardot pleads to Denmark in dolphin 'slaughter', AFP, 19 August 2010.

On 22 April 2011, French culture ministerFrdric Mitterrandofficially included bullfighting in the country's cultural heritage. Bardot wrote him a highly critical letter of protest.Victoria Ward, Devorah Lauter (4 January 2013)."Brigitte Bardot's sick elephants add to circus over French wealth tax protests", telegraph.co.uk; accessed 4 August 2015.

From 2013 onwards the Brigitte Bardot Foundation in collaboration with Kagyupa International Monlam Trust of India has operated annual Veterinary Care Camp. She has committed to the cause of animal welfare in Bodhgaya year after year.Bardot commits to animal welfare in Bodhgaya, phayul.com; accessed 4 August 2015.
article.heading: Politics and legal issues
article.paragraph: Bardot expressed support for PresidentCharles de Gaullein the 1960s.Her husband Bernard d'Ormale is a former adviser of theFront National (France)Front National, the main far right party in France, known for its nationalist and conservative beliefs.Happy birthday, Brigitte Bardot,The Guardian. 22 September 2009.cite newsDrinking champagne with: Brigitte Bardot; And God Created An Animal Lover By Alan Riding, published: 30 March 199414 January 2008http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res14 January 2008The New York Times

In her 1999 bookLe Carr de Pluton("Pluto's Square"), Bardot criticizes the procedure used in theritual slaughterof sheep during the Muslim festival ofEid al-Adha. Additionally, in a section in the book entitled, "Open Letter to My Lost France", Bardot writes that"my country, France, my homeland, my land is again invaded by an overpopulation of foreigners, especially Muslims". For this comment, a French court fined her 30,000 francs in June 2000. She had been fined in 1997 for the original publication of this open letter inLe Figaroand again in 1998 for making similar remarks.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/793390.stmBardot fined for racist remarksBBC News16 June 200013 March 2010Londoncite newsBBC News Bardot racism conviction upheld11 May 2001http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1324707.stm17 January 2008BBC NewsLondoncite newsBardot anti-Muslim comments draw fire14 May 2003http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3027955.stm17 January 2008BBC NewsLondonImage:BrigitteBardot.jpgthumb220pxBrigitte Bardot inNicein 2002.

In her 2003 book,Un cri dans le silence("A Scream in the Silence"), she warned of an "Islamicizationof France", and said of Muslim immigration:quote<arg name="''Over the last twenty years, we have given in to a subterranean, dangerous, and uncontrolled infiltration, which not only resists adjusting to our laws and customs but which will, as the years pass, attempt to impose its own.''<ref name">"Orland">{{cite news|title

In the book, she contrasted her close gay friends with today's homosexuals, who "jiggle their bottoms, put their little fingers in the air and with their little castrato voices moan about what those ghastly heteros put them through" and that some contemporary homosexuals behave like "fairground freaks".cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2003/may/15/france.davidhearstAnti-gay, anti-Islam Bardot to be suedWebsterPaulHearstDavid5 May 2003The GuardianUK3 October 2009In her own defence, Bardot wrote in a letter to a French gay magazine: "Apart from my husband who maybe will cross over one day as well I am entirely surrounded by homos. For years, they have been my support, my friends, my adopted children, my confidants."cite newsBrigitte a Political Animal by David Usborne24 March 2006http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20060324/ai_n16163852/pg_29 January 2008The Independenthttp://web.archive.org/web/20080424031103/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20060324/ai_n16163852/pg_224 April 2008

In her book she wrote about issues such as racial mixing, immigration, the role of women in politics and Islam. The book also contained a section attacking what she called the mixing of genes and praised previous generations who, she said, had given their lives to push out invaders.cite newsBardot fined for 'race hate' book10 June 2004http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3794513.stm3 June 2008BBC News

On 10 June 2004, Bardot was convicted for a fourth time by a French court for "inciting racial hatred" and fined 5,000.cite webLarentShermyhttp://www.indybay.org/news/2003/05/1610376.phpBrigitte Bardot unleashes colourful diatribe against Muslims and modern FranceIndybay12 May 200313 March 2010Bardot denied the racial hatred charge and apologized in court, saying: "I never knowingly wanted to hurt anybody. It is not in my character."cite newsBardot denies 'race hate' charge7 May 2003http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3692965.stm17 January 2008BBC News

In 2008, Bardot was convicted of inciting racial/religious hatred in relation to a letter she wrote, a copy of which she sent toNicolas Sarkozywhen he wasInterior Minister of France. The letter stated her objections to Muslims in FranceDhabihahritually slaughtering sheepby slitting their throats without anesthetizing them first. She also said, in reference to Muslims, that she was "fed up with being under the thumb of this population which is destroying us, destroying our country and imposing its habits". The trialcite webhttp://www.brusselsjournal.com/node/3177Brigitte Bardot: Heroine of Free SpeechBrusselsjournal.com13 March 2010concluded on 3 June 2008, with a conviction and fine of 15,000, the largest of her fines to date. The prosecutor stated that she was tired of charging Bardot with offences related to racial hatred.

During theUnited States presidential election, 20082008 United States presidential election, she branded theRepublican Party (United States)Republican Partyvice-presidential candidateSarah Palinas "stupid" and a "disgrace to women". She criticized the former governor of Alaska for her stance onglobal warmingandgun control. She was also offended by Palin's support for Arctic oil exploration and for her lack of consideration in protectingpolar bears."Brigitte Bardot calls Sarah Palin a 'disgrace to women'"The Telegraph, 8 October 2008.

On 13 August 2010, Bardot lashed out at directorKyle Newmanregarding his plan to make a biographical film on her life. She told him, "Wait until I'm dead before you make a movie about my life!" otherwise "sparks will fly".cite webhttp://www.showbizspy.com/article/210115/brigitte-bardot-wait-until-im-dead-before-you-make-a-movie-about-my-life.htmlBrigitte Bardot: ‘Wait Until I'M Dead Before You Make Biopic’Showbiz Spy14 August 201021 August 2010
article.heading: Influence in pop culture
article.paragraph: File:Bb buzios.jpgthumb215pxStatue of Brigitte Bardot inArmao dos BziosBuzios, BrazilInfashion, the Bardot neckline (a wide open neck that exposes both shoulders) is named after her. Bardot popularized this style which is especially used for knitted sweaters or jumpers although it is also used for other tops and dresses. Bardot popularized thebikiniin her early films such asManina, the Girl in the BikiniManina(1952) (released in France asManina, la fille sans voiles). The following year she was also photographed in a bikini on every beach in the south of France during theCannes Film Festival.cite webBikinis: a brief historyhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/picturegalleries/10160619/Bikinis-a-brief-history.html?frameTelegraph20 August 2013She gained additional attention when she filmedAnd God Created Woman (1956 film)...And God Created Woman(1956) withJean-Louis Trintignant(released in France asEt Dieu Cra La Femme). Bardot portrayed an immoral teenager cavorting in a bikini who seduces men in a respectable small-town setting. The film was an international success.The bikini was in the 1950s relatively well accepted in France but was still considered risqu in the United States. As late as 1959, Anne Cole, one of the United State's largest swimsuit designers, said, "It's nothing more than a G-string. It's at the razor's edge of decency."cite webWilliam OscarJohnson2013-10-02http://web.archive.org/web/20131020050948/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1068171/3/index.htmhttp://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1068171/3/index.htmIn The SwimSports Illustrated7 February 198918 August 2013

She also brought into fashion thechoucroute("Sauerkraut") hairstyle (a sort ofbeehive (hairstyle)beehive hair style) andginghamclothes after wearing a checkered pink dress, designed by Jacques Esterel, at her wedding to Charrier.cite webhttp://www.femminastyle.com/index.php?main_pageStyle Icon: Brigitte BardotFemminastyle.com13 March 2010She was the subject for anAndy Warholpainting.File:Lisboa 2012 005 (7736378402).jpgthumb215pxPainting of Brigitte Bardot inLisbon, Portugal.

In addition to popularizing the bikini swimming suit, Bardot has been credited with popularizing the city ofSt. Tropezand the town ofArmao dos Bziosin Brazil, which she visited in 1964 with her boyfriend at the time, Brazilian musicianBob Zagury. The place where she stayed in Bzios is today a small hotel, Pousada do Sol, and also a French restaurant, Cigalon.cite webTOemBUZIOS.comhttp://www.toembuzios.comTOemBUZIOS.com27 December 2012
A statue by Christina Mottacite webhttp://www.buziosonline.com.br/indexe.htmBuziosOnline.comBuziosOnline.com13 March 2010honours Brigitte Bardot inArmao dos Bzios.

Bardot was idolized by the youngJohn LennonandPaul McCartney.cite book[[Barry Miles|Miles, Barry]][[Many Years From Now]][[Vintage (publisher)|Vintage]]–[[Random House]]19980-7493-8658-4pg. 69cite book[[Bob Spitz|Spitz, Bob]]The Beatles: The Biography[[Little, Brown and Company]] (New York)20051-84513-160-6pg. 171They made plans to shoot a film featuringThe Beatlesand Bardot, similar toA Hard Day's Night (film)A Hard Day's Night, but the plans were never fulfilled.Lennon's first wifeCynthia Powelllightened her hair color to more closely resemble Bardot, whileGeorge Harrisonmade comparisons between Bardot and his first wifePattie Boyd, as Cynthia wrote later inA Twist of Lennon. Lennon and Bardot met in person once, in 1968 at the Mayfair Hotel, introduced by Beatles press agentDerek Taylor; a nervous Lennon tookLysergic acid diethylamideLSDbefore arriving, and neither star impressed the other. (Lennon recalled in a memoir, "I was on acid, and she was on her way out.")cite book[[John Lennon|Lennon, John]][[Skywriting by Word of Mouth]][[Harper Collins]]19860-06-015656-2pg. 24According to the liner notes of his first (self-titled) album, musicianBob Dylandedicated the first song he ever wrote to Bardot. He also mentioned her by name in "I Shall Be Free", which appeared on his second album,The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan. The first-ever official exhibition spotlighting Bardot's influence and legacy opened in Paris on 29 September 2009 a day after her 75th birthday.Brigitte Bardot at 75: the exhibition, connexionfrance.com, September 2009; accessed 4 August 2015.

A type ofCzechoslovakiaCzechoslovakDiesel locomotivediesel-electric locomotives:cs:Lokomotiva 751(Classes 751 and 749)manufactured in the 1960s/70s was nicknamed "Bardotka", reportedly because of the fact that the locomotive has a distinctively shaped front, resembling a woman's bosom.cnAugust 2015
